lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can revise and correctly use prepositions of place (e.g., next to, in front of, behind, between).
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Use a classroom object setup. Ask: “Where’s the pencil case?” Students respond with “It’s next to the board.” Practice with real items.
stretchStrategies: Classroom Preposition Maze – Rearrange classroom items into a mini “town.” In pairs, one student hides an object, then guides partner: “It’s behind the chair, next to the bag.” Partner follows to find it. Adds movement + grammar focus.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can complete sentences using correct prepositions of place.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Model on the board: “The ___ is ___ the ___.” Students write 3 sentences using visuals from the SB or classroom setup.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can pronounce words with a range of phonics sounds clearly and accurately.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

Certain common places will not overlap in style or popular concept with their Western equivalents (fire station, post office, bakery, library), whereas others are more comparable (hair salon, shopping centre)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
